sen.j: 星野 茂則（ほしの しげのり）は江戸時代前期の尾張藩士・弓術家。
sen.e: Shigenori HOSHINO is a clansman of the Owari Domain and a kyujutsu-ka (one who does kyujutsu, the art of Japanese archery) who lived during the early part of the Edo period.
Shigenori HOSHINO was a clansman of Owari Domain and an expert in kyujutsu (the art of Japanese archery) who lived during the early part of the Edo period.
Shigenori HOSHINO was a feudal retainer of the Owari clan and an expert in kyujutsu (the art of Japanese archery) who lived during the early part of the Edo period.

sen.j: 一般には星野勘左衛門の名で知られる。
sen.e: He is generally known under the name of Kanzaemon HOSHINO.
He is more usually known by the name of Kanzaemon HOSHINO.
He is more usually known by the name of Kanzaemon HOSHINO.

sen.j: 三十三間堂の通し矢で二度天下一の記録を樹立した。
sen.e: He set a record of number one in Japan twice, in the toshiya (long-range archery) at Sanjusangen-do Temple.
He twice set the record for the best archer in Japan at Sanjusangen-do Temple's archery competition, which required archers to shoot down a long, narrow corridor.
sen.cmt: Revised for clarity - added brief explanation of 通し矢
sen.e: He twice set the record for the best archer in Japan at Sanjusangen-do Temple's archery competition, which required archers to shoot down a long, narrow corridor.

sen.j: 生涯
sen.e: Biography
Biography
Biography

sen.j: 寛永19年(1642年)、星野伝右衛門則等の第三子として出生。
sen.e: He was born as the third child of Denemonnorito HOSHINO in 1642.
He was born as the third child of Denemonnorito HOSHINO in 1642.
He was born as the third child of Denemon Norito HOSHINO in 1642.

sen.j: 生誕地は現在の愛知県幡豆郡吉良町とされ、同町宮迫字四反田には生誕地や旧里の碑がある。
sen.e: His place of birth is said to be the current Kira-cho, Hazu District, Aichi Prefecture, and there are monuments as his place of birth and hometown in Aza Yontanda Miyasako of the same town.

He is said to have been born in what is now the town of Kira in Hazu District, Aichi Prefecture, and there are monuments to his place of birth and hometown in the Shitanda area of Miyasako in the same town.

He is said to have been born in what is now the town of Kira in Hazu County, Aichi Prefecture, and there are monuments to his place of birth and hometown in the Shitanda area of Miyasako in the same town.

sen.j: 星野氏は熱田神宮千秋氏の一族という。
sen.e: The HOSHINO clan is said to be a kin of the Senshu clan of the Atsuta-jingu Shrine.
The HOSHINO Clan is said to be related to the SENSHU Clan of Atsuta-jingu Shrine.
The Hoshino Clan is said to be related to the Senshu Clan of Atsuta-jingu Shrine.

sen.j: 茂則の祖父長右衛門則勝は平岩親吉の家臣で、親吉没後は竹腰正信の家臣となった。
sen.e: Shigenori's grandfather, Choemonnorikatsu, was a general of Chikayoshi HIRAIWA, and became a general of Masanobu TAKEKOSHI after Chikayoshi's death.
Shigenori's grandfather, Choemonnorikatsu, was a retainer of Chikayoshi HIRAIWA, and became a retainer of Masanobu TAKEKOSHI after Chikayoshi's death.
Shigenori's grandfather, Choemon Norikatsu, was a retainer of Chikayoshi HIRAIWA, and became a retainer of Masanobu TAKEKOSHI after Chikayoshi's death.

sen.j: 父の伝右衛門則等は徳川義直に仕え、馬廻・大道奉行・広敷足軽頭などを務めた。
sen.e: Shigenori's father, Denemonnorito, served under Yoshinao TOKUGAWA and worked as umamawari (a horse guard), daidobugyo (a magistrate), and hiroshiki ashigaru gashira (a head of foot soldiers), etc.

Shigenori's father, Denemonnorito, served under Yoshinao TOKUGAWA and held various posts including umamawari (horse guard), daidobugyo (magistrate), and hiroshiki ashigaru gashira (commander of foot soldiers).

Shigenori's father, Denemon Norito, served under Yoshinao TOKUGAWA and held various posts including umamawari (horse guard), daidobugyo (magistrate), and hiroshiki ashigaru gashira (commander of foot soldiers).

sen.j: 茂則は、尾張藩士で日置流竹林派（ちくりんは）の長屋忠重に師事して弓術を学び、徳川光友の代に弓役に任じられた。
sen.e: After learning kyujutsu by studying under Tadashige NAGAYA, who was a clansman of the Owari Domain and was of Hegi school, Chikurin line, Shigenori was appointed the yumiyaku (one responsible for archery duty) of Mitsutomo TOKUGAWA.
After learning kyujutsu from Owari clansman Tadashige NAGAYA of the Hegi-ryu Chikurin-ha school, Shigenori was appointed the yumiyaku (one responsible for archery duty) of Mitsutomo TOKUGAWA.
After learning kyujutsu from Owari feudal retainer Tadashige NAGAYA of the Hegi-ryu Chikurin-ha school, Shigenori was appointed the yumiyaku (one responsible for archery duty) of Mitsutomo TOKUGAWA.

sen.j: 寛文2年（1662年）5月28日 (旧暦)、京都三十三間堂で通し矢種目に挑み、総矢数10,025本中通し矢6,666本を記録し、紀州藩吉見台右衛門の記録を破り天下一となった。
sen.e: On July 13, 1662, he attended the toshiya event at Kyoto's Sanjusangen-do Temple, and set a record of 6,666 arrows out of a total of 10,025 arrows, broke the record of Daiemon YOSHIMI, a clansman of the Kishu Domain, and became number one in Japan.

On July 13, 1662, he took part in Sanjusangen-do Temple's archery contest in Kyoto and recorded 6,666 hits out of a total of 10,025 arrows, breaking the record of Daiemon YOSHIMI of Kishu Domain and making him the best archer in the country.

On July 13, 1662, he took part in Sanjusangen-do Temple's archery contest in Kyoto and recorded 6,666 hits out of a total of 10,025 arrows, breaking the record of Daiemon YOSHIMI of Kishu clan and making him the best archer in the country.

sen.j: この功で藩より弓頭に任じられ、知行高500石となった。
sen.e: As result of this achievement, he was appointed the yumigashira (a head of yumiyaku) by the domain and became the owner of a territory of 500 koku.
As result of this achievement, he was appointed the yumigashira (commander of archers) by the domain and awarded land worth 500 koku.
As result of this achievement, he was appointed the yumigashira (commander of archers) by the clan and awarded land worth 500 koku.

sen.j: 寛文8年、紀州藩葛西園右衛門が通し矢7,077本（総矢数9,000本）を達成し、記録更新される。
sen.e: In 1668, Sonoemon KASAI, a clansman of the Kishu Domain, set a record of 7,077 arrows out of a total of 9,000 arrows, breaking Shigenori's record.
In 1668, Sonoemon KASAI of Kishu Domain set a record of 7,077 hits out of a total of 9,000 arrows, breaking Shigenori's record.
In 1668, Sonoemon KASAI of Kishu clan set a record of 7,077 hits out of a total of 9,000 arrows, breaking Shigenori's record.

sen.j: 寛文9年（1669年）5月2日 (旧暦)に茂則は再度大矢数に挑み、総矢数10,542本中通し矢8,000本で葛西の記録を破り再度天下一となった。
sen.e: On May 31, 1669, Shigenori made another challenge, broke Sonoemon's record by succeeding in 8,000 arrows out of a total of 10,542 arrows, and once again became number one in Japan.
On May 31, 1669, Shigenori made another attempt and broke Sonoemon's record by scoring 8,000 hits out of a total of 10,542 arrows, once again becomig the best in Japan.
On May 31, 1669, Shigenori made another attempt and broke Sonoemon's record by scoring 8,000 hits out of a total of 10,542 arrows, once again becomig the best in Japan.

sen.j: この時は5月1日の時刻日本（午後6時）から始め、翌日正午、残り約6時間となったところで余力を残して打ち切ったと伝わる。
sen.e: According to legend, Shigenori began the shooting from 6:00 PM on May 30 and put an end to it at noon the next day, with about six hours remaining and with his energy still left.
According to legend, Shigenori began shooting at 6 o'clock in the evening on May 30 and finished at noon the next day, with about six hours remaining and with his energy still left.
According to legend, Shigenori began shooting at 6 o'clock in the evening on May 30 and finished at noon the next day, with about six hours remaining and with his energy still left.

sen.j: この記録達成により300石の加増を受けた。
sen.e: This achievement of record earned him additional 300 koku.
This achievement earned him an additional 300 koku.
This achievement earned him an additional 300 koku.

sen.j: 元禄9年（1696年）5月6日 (旧暦)死去、享年55。
sen.e: He died on June 5, 1696 at the age of fifty-five.
He died on June 5, 1696 at the age of fifty-five.
He died on June 5, 1696 at the age of 55.

sen.j: 子孫は尾張藩士として代々弓術の道統を継いだが、10代目の勘左衛門久則（明治39年〈1906年〉没）に嫡男がなく、富田常正が11代を継承した。
sen.e: His descendants succeeded kyujutsu for generations, but as the tenth-generation descendant, Hisanori (Kanzaemon) (deceased in 1906), had no legitimate son, Tsunemasa TOMITA succeeded as the eleventh-generation descendant.

His descendants passed on kyujutsu for generations, but the tenth-generation descendant, Hisanori (Kanzaemon) (deceased in 1906), had no legitimate son and so Tsunemasa TOMITA succeeded as the eleventh-generation descendant.

His descendants passed on kyujutsu for generations as Owari feudal retainers, but the 10th-generation descendant, Kanzaemon Hisanori (deceased in 1906), had no legitimate son and so Tsunemasa TOMITA succeeded as the 11th-generation descendant.
sen.cmt: 数字表記変更「尾張藩士として」、訳漏れを対応しました。Hisanori (Kanzaemon)→Kanzaemon Hisanoro

sen.j: 星野家の資料は近年の火災で多くが失われてしまったという。
sen.e: Most of the materials of the Hoshino family are said to have been lost in a recent fire.
Most of the Hoshino family's documents are said to have been lost in a recent fire.
Most of the Hoshino family's documents are said to have been lost in a recent fire.

sen.j: 逸話
sen.e: Anecdote
Anecdote
Anecdote

sen.j: 明良洪範後篇巻三に次のような逸話がある。
sen.e: There is the following anecdote in Meiryo-kohan historical records, Vol. III.
The following anecdote appears in the third volume of the Meiryo Kohan historical records.
The following anecdote appears in the third volume of the sequel to the Meiryo Kohan historical records.

sen.j: 勘左衛門は力持ちで知られていた。
sen.e: Kanzaemon was known as a man of great strength.
Kanzaemon was known as a man of great strength.
Kanzaemon was known as a man of great strength.

sen.j: 某日さる諸侯の家老を訪問した。
sen.e: One day he visited a chief retainer of a certain lord.
One day he visited the chief retainer of a certain lord.
One day he visited the chief retainer of a certain lord.

sen.j: 家老は相撲好きで、常に力士が出入りしており、その日も強力の力士が来ていた。
sen.e: The chief retainer being a lover of sumo wrestling, sumo wrestlers were always going in and out of his house; as such, a strong sumo wrestler happened to be visiting him that day.
The chief retainer being a lover of sumo wrestling, sumo wrestlers were always going in and out of his house; as such, a strong wrestler happened to be visiting him that day.
The chief retainer being a lover of sumo wrestling, sumo wrestlers were always going in and out of his house; as such, a strong wrestler happened to be visiting him that day.

sen.j: 亭主は勘左衛門に力士と相撲を取ることを所望した。
sen.e: The host asked Kanzaemon to wrestle with the sumo wrestler.
The host asked Kanzaemon to wrestle with the sumo wrestler.
The host asked Kanzaemon to wrestle with the sumo wrestler.

sen.j: 勘左衛門は再三辞したが、強いて所望されるのでやむを得ず取る事となった。
sen.e: As it turned out, Kanzaemon was compelled to wrestle in spite of having declined three times, since the host pushed him to do so.
Kanzaemon declined repeatedly but as his host insisted, he was left with no choice.
Kanzaemon declined repeatedly but as his host insisted, he was left with no choice.

sen.j: 勘左衛門は袴の裾を上げ大小を差したまま出てきたので皆不審に思い、行司が帯刀を見咎めたが、勘左衛門は以下のように答えた。
sen.e: When Kanzaemon appeared for the fight with the hem of his hakama (pleated and divided skirt made in fine stripes) tucked up and still carrying two swords, everyone grew suspicious and the sumo referee questioned him about it, but Kanzaemon replied as follows.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: When Kanzaemon appeared for the fight with the hem of his hakama (a kind of skirt worn over a kimono) tucked up and still carrying two swords, everyone grew suspicious and the sumo referee questioned him about it, but Kanzaemon replied,

When Kanzaemon appeared for the fight with the hem of his hakama (a kind of skirt worn over a kimono) tucked up and still carrying two swords, everyone grew suspicious and the sumo referee questioned him about it, but Kanzaemon replied as follows.
sen.cmt: 文末をオリジナル訳に戻しました。

sen.j: 「私は相撲取ではなく侍だ。」
sen.e: "I am a samurai and not a sumo wrestler."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: "I am a samurai and not a sumo wrestler.
sen.cmt: *I presume these three sentences are one speech so have revised the punctuation accordingly
sen.e: "I am a samurai and not a sumo wrestler."
sen.cmt: オリジナルに戻しました。

sen.j: 「亭主の望みで相手になるのだ。」
sen.e: "I am fighting upon the host's request."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: I am fighting upon the host's request.
sen.cmt: *I presume these three sentences are one speech so have revised the punctuation accordingly
sen.e: "I am fighting upon the host's request."
sen.cmt: オリジナルに戻しました。

sen.j: 「されば士の身として丸腰になるしきたりは無い」と答えた。」
sen.e: "As such, there is no rule according to which I have to be unarmed."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: As such, there is no rule according to which I have to be unarmed."
sen.cmt: *I presume these three sentences are one speech so have revised the punctuation accordingly
sen.e: "As such, there is no rule according to which I have to be unarmed."
sen.cmt: オリジナルに戻しました。

sen.j: 取り組うとすると勘左衛門は抜き打ちに相手を切り倒したので、皆大いに驚いた。
sen.e: When the fight began, Kanzaemon slashed down the opponent by surprise and greatly astonished everyone.
When the fight began, Kanzaemon drew his sword and in the same stroke, cut down his opponent, greatly astonishing everyone.
When the fight began, Kanzaemon drew his sword and in the same stroke, cut down his opponent, greatly astonishing everyone.

sen.j: 勘左衛門は刃を納めて亭主の前へ座し、「士が勝負を争う時はこうするものだと思われよ。と言って辞去した。
sen.e: Kanzaemon seated himself before the host after sheathing the sword, said as follows, and went away.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: Kanzaemon sheathed his sword and before leaving, seated himself before the host and said,
Kanzaemon sheathed his sword and before leaving, seated himself before the host and said, "Please know that this is the way the samurai fights."
sen.cmt: ＮＣチェックを考慮して原文、訳文ともに一文に戻しました。

sen.j: 亭主は心中では大いに怒ったが、どうしようもなくそのまま終わった。
sen.e: The host was very furious at heart but was helpless to do anything.
The host was inwardly furious but was helpless to do anything.
The host was inwardly furious but was helpless to do anything.

sen.j: 一座の人々は後で以下のように言ったという。
sen.e: It is said that people who witnessed the scene later talked as follows.
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: It is said that people who witnessed the scene later remarked that,
It is said that people who witnessed the scene later remarked as follows.
sen.cmt: 文末をオリジナル訳に戻しました。

sen.j: 「勘左衛門の対処はもっともな事だ。」
sen.e: "Kanzaemon reacted in a justifiable manner."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: "Kanzaemon reacted in a justifiable manner,"
"Kanzaemon reacted in a justifiable manner."
sen.cmt: オリジナルに戻しました。

sen.j: 「力士と士たる者との勝負を所望するのは失礼だ。」
sen.e: "It is rude to request for a fight between a sumo wrestler and a samurai."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: "It is rude to request a fight between a sumo wrestler and a samurai,"
"Kanzaemon reacted in a justifiable manner."
sen.cmt: 文末をピリオドに変更

sen.j: 「全く亭主の誤りだ。」
sen.e: "The host was completely at fault."
sen.cmt: 一原文一訳文の例外対処
sen.e: "The host was completely at fault."
"The host was completely at fault."
